quantityRules.description: House individually. Males are territorial and will fight. Females can sometimes be housed together in larger enclosures (40+ gallons) but monitor for aggression.

careTargets.gradient: Crepuscular species - active around sunset. Warm basking zone at top (82-85Â°F) with cooler areas below (70-75Â°F). Nighttime temperature drop to 65-72Â°F is natural and healthy.

temperament: Docile, tolerant of handling, can drop tail when stressed
setupTips: Young gargoyles (under 12g) benefit from a smaller 'grow out' enclosure (12Ã—12Ã—12) until large enough for adult setup
Use an infrared thermometer to measure temperatures throughout the enclosure - warmest at top, coolest at bottom
Mist enclosure morning and evening with tap water (contains essential minerals) - avoid distilled water
Place basking area as a vine, branch, or foliage cluster directly under heat lamp at top of enclosure
Provide vines, branches, and foliage at all vertical levels to allow proper thermoregulation
Use feeding ledges mounted at various heights for easy access to food bowls

warnings.message: Males MUST NEVER be housed together - they are extremely territorial and will fight to the death. Only attempt housing multiple females with larger enclosure (40+ gallons) and careful monitoring.
Can drop their tail when stressed or frightened. Unlike crested geckos, tails may partially regenerate but will never look the same. Handle gently and avoid grabbing by tail.
Consistent temperatures above 85Â°F can cause heat stress. Nighttime drop to 65-72Â°F is natural and beneficial - don't use ceramic heat emitters at night unless room drops below 60Â°F.
Humidity consistently below 50% causes shedding problems and dehydration. Humidity constantly above 85% promotes bacterial/fungal growth. Aim for 60-80% average with natural daily fluctuation.
Feeder insects should never be larger than the space between the gecko's eyes. Oversized prey can cause impaction or choking.
Front-opening enclosures are strongly preferred over top-opening. Reaching from above triggers predator response and causes stress.
